title: D.I.P.L.O.M.A.T (Deans and Internationalization Program Leaders Organizing Multinational Academic Transformation)

content: In today’s globalized world, higher education institutions increasingly prioritize internationalization as a crucial driver of academic excellence, research collaboration, and cultural exchange. To stay competitive and relevant globally, university leadership must grasp the complexities of international engagement and develop strategies that embed global perspectives across their institutional mission. The DIPLOMAT training program is designed to equip deans and program heads with the knowledge, skills, and tools needed to successfully lead their institutions through this process. By deepening their understanding of global trends, cross-cultural collaboration, and strategic international partnerships, the program promotes a comprehensive approach to academic transformation that enriches the experiences of both faculty and students.

sections.title: This projects aims to:
items: Provide deans and program heads with the leadership skills necessary to guide their institutions through the complexities of internationalization, fostering an inclusive and globally-minded academic environment.

Equip participants with the ability to design, implement, and evaluate internationalization strategies that align with the institution’s mission and vision, ensuring that international initiatives are sustainable and impactful.
Cultivate an understanding of cultural differences, enabling deans and program heads to promote diversity and inclusion within academic programs and international partnerships.

sections.title: Contributions to the Sustainable Development Goals
content: The benchmarking seminar organized under the D.I.P.L.O.M.A.T initiative made meaningful contributions to advancing several United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) by fostering dialogue, strategic planning, and cross-cultural learning among academic leaders. It directly supported SDG 4: Quality Education by promoting internationalization to enhance educational standards, encouraging the integration of global perspectives into curricula to better prepare students for a connected world. The seminar also advanced SDG 10: Reduced Inequalities by fostering cultural awareness and inclusivity, enabling institutions to expand equal access to global opportunities like scholarships and exchanges, thereby empowering underrepresented communities. Aligning with SDG 17: Partnerships for the Goals, the event facilitated international cooperation through discussions on joint research, student mobility, and faculty exchanges, building sustainable academic networks for shared development. Supporting SDG 9: Industry, Innovation, and Infrastructure, it encouraged innovation in curriculum and institutional strategies by adopting international best practices, enhancing research capacity to meet societal needs. The seminar promoted SDG 5: Gender Equality by emphasizing inclusive leadership development and gender-balanced representation among academic leaders, fostering equitable and responsive academic environments. Finally, it contributed to SDG 16: Peace, Justice, and Strong Institutions by equipping leaders with governance strategies based on transparency, ethical leadership, and cross-cultural understanding, reinforcing universities’ roles in nurturing civic values and resilient societies.

columns.title: General Assessment
content: The benchmarking activity under the D.I.P.L.O.M.A.T initiative was highly successful in achieving its goals. It effectively enhanced the leadership skills of academic heads, promoted strategic internationalization, and fostered valuable institutional partnerships. Participants gained practical insights on curriculum development, global collaboration, and inclusive education. The event was well-organized, with engaging sessions and credible speakers, creating a productive and collaborative learning environment. Overall, the activity made a significant contribution to the internationalization efforts of participating institutions and reinforced their alignment with global educational and development goals.

columns.title: Recommendations
content: To enhance the effectiveness of future seminar activities, it is recommended that participating institutions establish a formal communication network to support ongoing collaboration and knowledge exchange. Regular seminar activities focusing on themes such as curriculum internationalization, digital learning, and global research should be conducted to promote continuous improvement. Participants are encouraged to develop actionable plans that integrate the seminar's insights into institutional strategies, with clear indicators for monitoring and evaluation. Involving a broader group of stakeholders, including students, international partners, and industry experts, is also advised to enrich future engagements. Lastly, adopting hybrid or online formats will enable wider participation and foster inclusivity, particularly for institutions with limited resources.

The higher education landscape is rapidly evolving, presenting challenges such as technological advancements, globalization, and shifting societal needs that require strong, adaptable leadership. Yet many emerging academic leaders lack access to structured mentoring and professional development. The Higher Education Leadership Mentoring Seminar (HELMS) aims to bridge this gap by offering a platform where participants can learn from experienced mentors, cultivate essential leadership skills, and build a network of peers and experts. Focused on fostering transformative leadership that champions innovation, inclusivity, and excellence, HELMS brings together higher education leaders, policymakers, and industry experts to empower participants with the knowledge and tools needed to drive meaningful change. This initiative reflects a core belief that effective leadership is vital to the sustainability and growth of academic institutions.

sections.title: This projects aims to:
items: Equip emerging leaders with essential leadership skills and strategies for higher education.
Facilitate mentorship opportunities between experienced leaders and participants.
Promote best practices in leadership, including strategic planning, change management, and stakeholder engagement.
Foster a network of professionals committed to advancing higher education.

sections.title: Contributions to the Sustainable Development Goals
content: The Higher Education Leadership Mentoring Seminar (HELMS) made a significant contribution to several United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), demonstrating its commitment to inclusive, high-quality, and transformative education. Primarily aligned with SDG 4: Quality Education, HELMS equipped current and emerging academic leaders with critical skills in leadership, strategic planning, and institutional management—key competencies for strengthening educational institutions and enhancing the delivery of quality education. The seminar also supported SDG 5: Gender Equality by fostering a safe, inclusive environment that encouraged equal participation of men and women, with female leaders actively represented among both mentors and participants. In alignment with SDG 10: Reduced Inequalities, HELMS provided equitable access to leadership development for individuals from diverse institutions, regardless of geographic location, funding level, or institutional status, thereby promoting inclusivity across the academic landscape. Additionally, the program addressed SDG 16: Peace, Justice, and Strong Institutions by emphasizing ethical leadership, integrity, emotional intelligence, and accountability—principles essential to building resilient and transparent institutions. Reflecting the spirit of SDG 17: Partnerships for the Goals, HELMS brought together stakeholders from academia, government, and the private sector, reinforcing the importance of cross-sector collaboration in driving sustainable progress. Through these efforts, HELMS not only fostered individual leadership development but also enhanced the capacity of higher education institutions to contribute meaningfully to national and global development agendas.

columns.title: General Assessment
content: The Higher Education Leadership Mentoring Seminar was successfully implemented and well-received by the participants. The program’s structure, which combined expert insights, interactive workshops, and mentoring sessions, provided a balanced and engaging learning experience. Participants actively engaged in discussions, shared their experiences, and expressed appreciation for the opportunity to connect with seasoned leaders in the field. The sessions were relevant, timely, and aligned with the goals of leadership development in the higher education sector. Feedback gathered from participants highlighted the effectiveness of the mentoring circles and the value of practical strategies shared during the workshops and panel discussions. The event was well-organized, with smooth facilitation, active participation, and strong logistical support, contributing to the overall success of the seminar.

columns.title: Recommendations
content: To further enhance the impact of future leadership seminars, it is recommended to extend the duration of mentoring sessions to allow for deeper engagement and more personalized guidance. Incorporating follow-up activities such as online mentoring, leadership webinars, or progress check-ins can sustain the momentum and ensure continuous learning. It is also suggested to diversify the pool of mentors and speakers to include leaders from various sectors such as government, industry, and international institutions, offering broader perspectives. Lastly, gathering more structured feedback through post-event surveys and reflective reports will help in refining the program design and aligning future activities with participants’ evolving needs and institutional goals.

title: HEROE: Harnessing Engagement and Resilience through Online Exchange — A COIL-Based NSTP Initiative Integrating the Sustainable Development Goals

content: In today’s increasingly interconnected world, fostering global citizenship, intercultural competence, and sustainable leadership among students is more critical than ever. The National Service Training Program (NSTP) in the Philippines, as a civic education initiative, presents a valuable opportunity to integrate the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) into student learning. In response, Urdaneta City University proposes the project HEROE: Harnessing Engagement and Resilience through Online Exchange. Designed to enhance NSTP delivery, HEROE incorporates Collaborative Online International Learning (COIL) methodologies that connect students with international peers through virtual exchanges. This approach deepens students' understanding of global issues such as poverty, inequality, climate action, peacebuilding, and community resilience—key themes within the SDGs. By participating in structured COIL experiences, NSTP instructors and students will co-create culturally informed solutions and develop civic projects with global relevance. This transformative initiative not only enriches the NSTP curriculum but also positions UCU as a forward-looking institution dedicated to inclusive, sustainable, and globally engaged education.

sections.title: This projects aims to:
items: Integrate the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) into the NSTP through COIL-based activities and collaborative projects.
Empower NSTP instructors to design and implement virtual exchange modules that promote civic responsibility, intercultural dialogue, and sustainability awareness.
Enhance global competencies among NSTP students through direct engagement with international peers on SDG-focused issues.

sections.title: Contributions to the Sustainable Development Goals
content: The HEROE project significantly advances the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) by promoting inclusive, quality education (SDG 4) through its innovative use of Collaborative Online International Learning (COIL). By facilitating virtual exchanges between students and international partners, HEROE enhances intercultural competence, critical thinking, and global citizenship, thereby enriching the NSTP learning experience. It also contributes to reducing inequalities (SDG 10) by connecting students from diverse cultural and geographic backgrounds, empowering them to engage in meaningful global dialogue and collaborative problem-solving. Addressing urgent global issues, HEROE fosters climate action (SDG 13) by encouraging students to develop awareness and sustainable solutions through joint civic projects. In addition, it supports peace, justice, and strong institutions (SDG 16) by nurturing civic engagement and peacebuilding skills among future leaders. The project exemplifies the spirit of partnerships for the goals (SDG 17) through international collaboration that promotes knowledge exchange and shared action toward sustainable development. Through these multifaceted contributions, HEROE not only strengthens NSTP’s alignment with global development priorities but also prepares students to become resilient, responsible, and globally engaged citizens.

columns.title: General Assessment
content: The HEROE event was a successful and impactful initiative that effectively introduced and promoted the integration of Collaborative Online International Learning (COIL) within the National Service Training Program (NSTP) at Urdaneta City University. By aligning with the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), the event provided students with a valuable opportunity to engage in virtual exchanges with international peers, fostering intercultural competence and global citizenship. The insightful presentations from key speakers, including Dr. Mary Ruth Cinchez and Dr. Sonny Soriano, along with student testimonials, enriched the dialogue around global challenges and sustainable leadership. The interactive Q&A session and networking opportunities further enhanced collaboration among students, faculty, and international partners. Overall, the event highlighted UCU's commitment to fostering socially responsible and globally aware students, paving the way for future projects that encourage sustainable development and cross-cultural engagement.

columns.title: Recommendations
content: For future iterations of the HEROE event, it is recommended to expand the scope of international collaborations by inviting a broader range of partner institutions from diverse regions, especially those from underserved or less-represented countries. This would deepen the global perspective and enrich the students’ learning experience by exposing them to a wider array of cultural contexts and sustainable development challenges. Additionally, incorporating more hands-on, project-based activities during the virtual exchanges could provide students with practical experiences in addressing real-world issues. To further enhance the impact of the event, it may be beneficial to integrate follow-up activities or workshops that allow students to apply their learnings to local community projects, thereby strengthening the connection between global knowledge and local action. Finally, improving accessibility by offering the event in multiple languages or providing translation services could facilitate greater participation from non-English-speaking partners and students, ensuring a more inclusive and diverse exchange.

title: KIZUNA LITE: Cultural Exchange and Community Care for Young Learners

content: “Kizuna Lite” is a scaled outreach and extension program focusing on promoting cultural appreciation, basic educational support, and well-being for children through a collaborative effort between UCU and a Japanese partner. This program aims to uplift underprivileged pupils by providing school supplies, shared cultural experiences, and a one-day feeding and fun-learning event, all designed to strengthen cross-cultural friendship and social responsibility.

sections.title: This projects aims to:
items: Foster mutual understanding between Filipino and Japanese learners through simple cultural exchange activities.
Provide essential school supplies to help equip pupils for the academic year.
Promote well-being through a nutritious feeding program for the participating pupils.
Engage UCU students and staff in meaningful service and cultural ambassadorship.

sections.title: Contributions to the Sustainable Development Goals
content: The "Kizuna Lite" program contributes meaningfully to multiple United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) through its holistic, inclusive, and collaborative approach. Addressing SDG 1: No Poverty, the program provides essential school supplies that ease the financial burden on families from marginalized communities. It supports SDG 3: Good Health and Well-Being through feeding activities that enhance the nutritional status and overall development of children. In alignment with SDG 4: Quality Education, the distribution of learning materials improves access to education and encourages school attendance among young learners. By reaching underserved populations, Kizuna Lite advances SDG 10: Reduced Inequalities, helping bridge gaps in access to resources and opportunities. The program also promotes SDG 16: Peace, Justice, and Strong Institutions by fostering cultural understanding and inclusive relationships among students of different nationalities. Furthermore, it exemplifies SDG 17: Partnerships for the Goals through the transnational collaboration between Urdaneta City University and its Japanese counterpart, highlighting the power of global cooperation in driving sustainable development.

columns.title: General Assessment
content: The successful implementation of the “Kizuna Lite” program achieved its core objectives of promoting cultural awareness, supporting education, and enhancing the health and well-being of underprivileged children. Well-structured and engaging activities fostered meaningful interaction between UCU volunteers and the pupils, creating a lively, educational environment that blended fun with learning. The cultural exchange sessions were particularly impactful, sparking curiosity about Japanese culture among the children while allowing UCU students to serve as cultural facilitators and ambassadors. The distribution of school supplies effectively met the beneficiaries’ basic educational needs, instilling a sense of preparedness and motivation for the new school year. Personalized messages included with the supplies added a heartfelt touch, strengthening emotional connections and encouragement. The feeding program not only addressed nutritional needs but also delivered key lessons on health and hygiene, promoting holistic development. Strong collaboration among university units, student volunteers, and the international partner was evident throughout, highlighting the potential of extension and outreach programs to generate meaningful grassroots impact. The enthusiastic involvement of all stakeholders, along with positive feedback from pupils, school staff, and community members, affirms the relevance and effectiveness of “Kizuna Lite” as a model for culturally sensitive, student-led civic engagement.

columns.title: Recommendations
content: To further enhance the impact and sustainability of the “Kizuna Lite” program, several key recommendations are proposed. First, strengthening pre-activity orientation and training for UCU volunteers is essential, including sessions on Japanese culture and child engagement techniques to ensure facilitators are well-prepared and culturally sensitive. Establishing ongoing communication with the Japanese partner school—through regular video exchanges or a pen-pal program—can deepen cross-cultural relationships beyond a single event. Expanding the program’s reach by involving more beneficiaries or replicating it in other public schools is also recommended, potentially supported by partnerships with local government units and community organizations. Involving teachers and parents through orientations or feedback sessions can reinforce lessons learned and create a more supportive environment for the pupils. Developing a basic monitoring and evaluation tool, such as surveys or interviews, will help gather participant feedback to assess effectiveness and guide future improvements. Enhancing the health component by collaborating further with UCU’s health-related departments can provide ongoing guidance on nutrition and hygiene beyond the event. Lastly, documenting the program through photos, testimonials, and success stories will support promotion, knowledge sharing, and inspire similar initiatives within and beyond the university.

title: PASSION-Preparing Active Students for Sustainability, Innovation, and Outreach for Nations Seminar

content: Amid growing environmental, social, and economic challenges, there is an urgent need to cultivate students who are not only knowledgeable but also actively engaged in creating sustainable solutions. The PASSION – Preparing Active Students for Sustainability, Innovation, and Outreach for Nations Seminar addresses this by equipping students with the tools, mindset, and networks needed to drive positive change. Recognizing sustainability as a critical global priority, the seminar emphasizes innovative approaches that balance economic growth with environmental stewardship and social equity, while community outreach ensures these efforts remain inclusive and connected to real-world contexts. Through this platform, students develop leadership skills, deepen their understanding of sustainable development, and engage meaningfully with their communities. By fostering active participation and interdisciplinary learning, PASSION aims to nurture future leaders ready to contribute effectively to their nations’ sustainable development goals, inspire innovation, and champion social responsibility.

sections.title: This projects aims to:
items: Equip student leaders with the skills to advocate for and implement SDG-driven initiatives.
Foster gender-responsive leadership and inclusive governance.
Promote innovative problem-solving and sustainability practices.
Provide networking opportunities for collaboration and outreach.

sections.title: Contributions to the Sustainable Development Goals
content: The PASSION Seminar plays a crucial role in advancing multiple Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) by providing students with quality education focused on sustainability, innovation, and active community engagement. It supports SDG 4 by delivering inclusive and equitable education that equips students with the skills necessary to address complex global challenges. By fostering innovative thinking, the seminar contributes to SDG 9, encouraging the development of new technologies and sustainable infrastructures. Through community outreach, PASSION promotes sustainable cities and communities in line with SDG 11, helping students learn to build resilient and inclusive environments. Additionally, the seminar raises awareness of responsible consumption and production (SDG 12) by teaching students how to minimize waste and use resources efficiently, while empowering them to take climate action consistent with SDG 13. Importantly, PASSION strengthens partnerships among students, educators, and communities, aligning with SDG 17, which is vital for sustainable development. Together, these efforts prepare students to become proactive leaders who contribute meaningfully to their nations and the global community.

columns.title: General Assessment
content: The PASSION Seminar successfully achieved its goal of preparing students to become active contributors to sustainability, innovation, and community development. The program provided valuable opportunities for participants to deepen their understanding of the Sustainable Development Goals, develop leadership skills, and engage in creative problem-solving through innovation and action planning sessions. The inclusion of networking and collaborative activities effectively fostered connections among students, faculty, and external stakeholders, which is crucial for sustaining long-term partnerships. Overall, the seminar was well-organized, engaging, and relevant to the current needs of students and their communities.

columns.title: Recommendations
content: To enhance the impact of future iterations of the seminar, it is recommended to include more hands-on project implementation opportunities where students can immediately apply their learning in real-world settings. Incorporating follow-up sessions or mentoring programs could help sustain motivation and track the progress of student-led initiatives. Additionally, expanding the involvement of external partners from various sectors can provide a broader range of perspectives and resources. Finally, collecting more detailed feedback from participants will help tailor content and activities to better address their needs and challenges.

title: BENCHMARKING ACTIVITY with Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng San Pablo

content: Benchmarking is a strategic approach that promotes institutional learning, continuous improvement, and academic collaboration. In its pursuit of excellence in higher education, Urdaneta City University (UCU) is honored to host a benchmarking activity with Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng San Pablo (PLSP). This collaborative engagement allows both institutions to benefit from mutual learning and institutional strengthening, reinforcing UCU’s role as a model institution while providing PLSP with valuable insights to enhance its academic and operational frameworks. Additionally, the initiative offers UCU opportunities for reflection and improvement, supporting sustained growth and leadership in higher education. Through this partnership, UCU reaffirms its commitment to fostering a culture of excellence, innovation, and collaboration, advancing educational quality and community transformation.

sections.title: This projects aims:
items: Showcasing UCU’s strategies and best practices in becoming a Local Economic Enterprise to support financial sustainability and community impact.
Highlighting innovative teaching methodologies and curriculum enhancements in the College of Teacher Education and the College of Business Administration to promote academic excellence.
Providing insights into UCU’s Level III Accreditation preparation and Quality Assurance mechanisms to guide PLSP’s accreditation efforts.

sections.title: Contributions to the Sustainable Development Goals
content: The benchmarking activity between Urdaneta City University (UCU) and Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng San Pablo (PLSP) advances several Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) by promoting quality education, fostering innovation, and building strong partnerships. Through this collaboration, both institutions enhance their educational frameworks and share best practices that improve teaching and learning experiences, aligning with SDG 4: Quality Education. The partnership cultivates a culture of continuous learning and innovation, contributing to SDG 9: Industry, Innovation, and Infrastructure by encouraging the adoption of innovative practices and technologies in higher education. Moreover, the exchange of knowledge and resources exemplifies SDG 17: Partnerships for the Goals, strengthening institutional networks that support mutual growth and development. This collaboration also addresses SDG 10: Reduced Inequalities by helping bridge gaps in educational quality and accessibility, particularly for underserved communities, ensuring a more inclusive academic environment. Additionally, the universities’ commitment to community-driven initiatives and sustainable practices supports SDG 11: Sustainable Cities and Communities, benefiting local social and economic development while reducing environmental impact. The activity further contributes to SDG 8: Decent Work and Economic Growth by enhancing educational programs that prepare graduates for successful careers, thereby supporting local economies. Finally, by prioritizing the well-being of students and faculty, the partnership promotes SDG 3: Good Health and Well-Being, fostering healthier and more supportive academic environments. Collectively, UCU and PLSP’s benchmarking effort drives a more inclusive, innovative, and sustainable higher education landscape that advances both institutional growth and community transformation.

columns.title: General Assessment
content: The benchmarking activity between Urdaneta City University (UCU) and Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng San Pablo (PLSP) was an engaging and well-organized event that successfully promoted academic collaboration and institutional growth. The program showcased UCU’s academic strengths, including its internationalization efforts, best practices in teacher education, and strategies for research and community engagement. Led by UCU faculty and administrators, each session provided valuable insights that PLSP could adapt to improve its own academic and operational frameworks. The event facilitated meaningful knowledge exchange, covering important topics such as accreditation preparation, faculty development, and community-based research. Overall, the activity nurtured a spirit of shared learning and partnership, strengthening the relationship between the two universities and advancing their mutual commitment to continuous improvement.

columns.title: Recommendations
content: To enhance the effectiveness of future benchmarking activities, it is recommended that the same strategies used in this activity—such as the diverse range of presentations, interactive workshops, and knowledge-sharing sessions—be applied again. These methods proved successful in fostering engagement and allowing participants to gain valuable insights. Continuing with the current format of having a mix of academic presentations, practical discussions, and strategic planning will ensure that the activity remains informative and productive. Additionally, incorporating the same collaborative approach, with faculty, administrators, and staff from both universities participating, should be maintained. This strategy encourages diverse perspectives and fosters stronger partnerships. Lastly, the structured feedback mechanism and follow-up initiatives used in this program should also be retained, as they proved effective in ensuring that both institutions could track progress and implement improvements based on the insights gained. By continuing these strategies, the benchmarking activity will remain a key tool for institutional development and academic collaboration in the future.

title: SEMINAR TRAINING on Enhancing Research and Extension Capacities for Internationalization and Global University Rankings

content: Global university rankings emphasize research productivity, global partnerships, and sustainable extension programs. As Urdaneta City University strives for internationalization, this seminar-training will equip Research and Extension Coordinators with the necessary tools to enhance their contributions to these ranking systems. Participants will explore key indicators such as research impact, international collaborations, and SDG-aligned extension initiatives.

sections.title: This projects aims:
items: Enhance faculty and coordinators’ understanding of international research and extension framework.
Develop strategies for international research partnerships and publications.
Strengthen documentation and reporting of research and extension activities.

sections.title: Contributions to the Sustainable Development Goals
content: The seminar-training on Enhancing Research and Extension Capacities for Internationalization and Global University Rankings made significant contributions to advancing the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) by strengthening higher education’s role in promoting inclusive, sustainable, and globally responsive development. Primarily, it supported SDG 4: Quality Education by advancing internationalization as a strategy to elevate academic standards through capacity-building and the integration of global frameworks into research and extension activities, thereby creating dynamic, future-ready learning environments. The seminar also addressed SDG 10: Reduced Inequalities by promoting equitable access to international academic opportunities, empowering faculty and students—especially those from underrepresented groups—to engage in cross-border collaborations and inclusive extension programs. Aligning with SDG 17: Partnerships for the Goals, it fostered international linkages through discussions on joint publications, co-hosted conferences, and collaborative research, laying foundations for long-term global partnerships. Furthermore, the training supported SDG 9: Industry, Innovation, and Infrastructure by inspiring innovation in research and institutional planning, enabling modernization and the development of robust research ecosystems. It also advanced SDG 5: Gender Equality by promoting inclusive academic leadership and balanced participation in governance, reinforcing gender equity within higher education. Lastly, the seminar contributed to SDG 16: Peace, Justice, and Strong Institutions by advocating ethical, transparent leadership and responsible governance, strengthening institutional capacities to uphold academic integrity and foster resilient, peace-building educational environments. Through these efforts, the seminar-training reaffirmed Urdaneta City University’s dedication to the SDGs and its strategic pursuit of excellence in research, extension, and international engagement.

columns.title: General Assessment
content: The seminar-training on “Enhancing Research and Extension Capacities for Internationalization and Global University Rankings” was successfully conducted, achieving its objectives with strong engagement from UCU faculty, deans, program heads, and guests from partner institutions. The well-organized sessions offered valuable insights on improving research, extension activities, and global rankings, covering topics such as research metrics, international collaboration, SDG alignment, and documentation strategies. Participants found the workshops and discussions highly relevant and informative, appreciating the introduction to global frameworks like UI GreenMetric, Times Higher Education (THE), and WURI. The event also fostered the exchange of ideas and best practices among attendees. Overall, the seminar significantly strengthened UCU’s drive toward internationalization and academic excellence, marking an important step in developing research and extension programs that meet global standards.

columns.title: Recommendations
content: It is recommended that follow-up workshops be conducted to further train faculty and coordinators on specific topics such as international research publication, extension impact reporting, and partnership development. Strengthening international linkages should also be prioritized by establishing formal collaborations with foreign institutions for research, faculty exchanges, and joint academic projects. To support global competitiveness, the university should improve the documentation of research outputs and extension activities in line with international ranking standards. In addition, the university is encouraged to promote and support projects that align with the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), particularly those focused on education, innovation, and community engagement. Finally, it is suggested that a monitoring team be created to oversee the implementation of these strategies and ensure continued progress toward the university’s internationalization efforts.

title: College of Education Behind Bars Benchmarking Activity

content: The College of Education Behind Bars Benchmarking Activity took place on [Insert exact date] at Davao del Norte State College (DNSC) in Panabo City, Davao del Norte, aiming to explore effective strategies for implementing education programs for Persons Deprived of Liberty (PDLs). DNSC has established a strong track record in managing its Education Behind Bars initiative, offering accessible and quality higher education to incarcerated individuals to equip them with relevant skills and academic qualifications that support their rehabilitation and reintegration into society. As part of its commitment to inclusive education, community engagement, and transformative learning, Urdaneta City University’s (UCU) College of Education conducted this benchmarking visit to better understand the processes, policies, and partnerships needed to replicate such a program within its own context. Through direct discussions, site visits, and consultations with DNSC officials, UCU gained valuable insights into program design, curriculum adaptation, stakeholder engagement, and operational sustainability.

sections.title: This projects aims to:
items: Learn best practices from DNSC in the implementation of the Education Behind Bars program.
Understand the processes and requirements involved in establishing similar educational programs for PDLs.
Develop an outline and framework for UCU to follow in conducting its own College of Education Behind Bars initiative.

sections.title: Contributions to the Sustainable Development Goals
content: Urdaneta City University’s program aligns with several Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs): SDG 4 (Quality Education) by adopting inclusive education models that extend learning opportunities to marginalized and underserved sectors, ensuring no one is left behind; SDG 10 (Reduced Inequalities) by addressing barriers to education faced by Persons Deprived of Liberty (PDLs), promoting equal access to knowledge and skills; SDG 16 (Peace, Justice, and Strong Institutions) by supporting rehabilitation, reintegration, and reducing recidivism rates through education, thereby fostering a more just and equitable society; and SDG 17 (Partnerships for the Goals) by encouraging collaboration among academic institutions, government agencies, and civil society to achieve shared development objectives.

columns.title: General Assessment
content: The benchmarking activity proved highly informative and strategic in shaping UCU’s future implementation of the College of Education Behind Bars program, with DNSC’s experience highlighting the crucial roles of strong institutional commitment, inter-agency collaboration, and a learner-centered approach. The visit confirmed that successful programs demand careful planning, clear operational guidelines, and sustained partnerships, and the insights gained will serve as a practical blueprint for UCU to design and launch its own impactful and sustainable initiative.

columns.title: Recommendations
content: Develop a comprehensive implementation framework for UCU’s Education Behind Bars program that incorporates best practices from DNSC, establishes formal partnerships with BJMP, local government units, and NGOs to secure support and resources, conducts internal capacity-building for faculty and staff involved in program delivery, integrates monitoring and evaluation mechanisms to assess effectiveness and drive continuous improvement, and promotes the initiative within the UCU community to foster volunteerism, resource-sharing, and advocacy for inclusive education.

title: CHR Region I Training-Workshop on Human Rights

content: In the context of national development and democratic governance, understanding and promoting human rights is a crucial responsibility for educational institutions and youth leaders. To support this, the Commission on Human Rights – Region I organized a Training-Workshop on Human Rights as part of the International Youth Day 2025 celebrations. The event aimed to raise awareness, foster respect, and encourage advocacy for human rights among student leaders, SK officials, and youth volunteers by providing an interactive platform to learn about fundamental human rights concepts, examine real-life issues affecting communities, and build capacity for rights-based leadership. By bringing together youth representatives and human rights practitioners, the workshop facilitated dialogue, strengthened skills, and promoted collaboration, thereby helping to nurture a culture of dignity, equality, and justice within communities.

sections.title: This projects aims to:
items: Promote human rights education and awareness among student leaders, youth volunteers, and youth organizations.
Encourage active engagement of young people in the promotion and protection of human rights at the grassroots level.
Build the capacity of youth participants in identifying and responding to human rights issues in their communities.

sections.title: Contributions to the Sustainable Development Goals
content: The CHR Region I Training-Workshop on Human Rights significantly advanced several United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), illustrating how human rights education serves as a powerful catalyst for sustainable development. The workshop highlighted the essential role of informed and empowered youth in promoting equality, reinforcing democratic values, and addressing the social challenges outlined in the SDGs. It notably supported SDG 4: Quality Education by equipping youth leaders with knowledge of fundamental rights and legal frameworks, fostering inclusive, equitable, and rights-based education, and empowering participants to advocate for human rights within their communities, thereby enhancing access to knowledge and civic awareness. In addressing SDG 5: Gender Equality, the workshop engaged youth leaders in discussions on gender-based discrimination, equal participation, and women’s empowerment, encouraging both male and female participants to challenge harmful norms and promote safety, inclusion, and equal opportunity. It contributed to SDG 10: Reduced Inequalities by empowering marginalized youth to actively engage in civic and decision-making processes, creating a safe space for diverse voices and promoting equitable leadership opportunities to help lessen social and economic disparities. Relating to SDG 16: Peace, Justice, and Strong Institutions, the training fostered a culture of peace, respect for the rule of law, and active civic participation, deepening participants’ understanding of justice systems, accountability, and the role of citizens in democratic governance through real-life human rights cases. Finally, the workshop reinforced SDG 17: Partnerships for the Goals by cultivating collaboration among the Commission on Human Rights, Urdaneta City University, and various youth organizations, thereby strengthening collective capacity to advocate for human rights, mobilize resources, and implement impactful community-based initiatives.

columns.title: General Assessment
content: The CHR Region I Training-Workshop on Human Rights was a highly successful and impactful event that effectively achieved its goals of raising awareness, building capacity, and fostering partnerships for human rights advocacy. By combining foundational concepts with practical, real-world applications, the workshop empowered youth leaders to promote equality, uphold democratic values, and address critical social issues within their communities. Resource speakers from the Commission on Human Rights – Region I provided expert insights grounded in actual cases, while interactive sessions enabled participants to translate theory into actionable strategies, creating a clear roadmap for integrating human rights advocacy into youth-led initiatives. The event also fostered an engaging and inclusive environment, bringing together diverse participants—from student organizations, SK officials, youth volunteers, to community leaders—which enriched discussions and reinforced the shared responsibility of protecting human rights across sectors. Strongly aligned with the Sustainable Development Goals, especially those on education, equality, and institutional strength, the workshop encouraged participants to reflect on how human rights principles intersect with sustainable development and apply these insights in local advocacy efforts. Despite its success, suggestions for improvement included extending the duration for deeper exploration of complex topics, incorporating more localized case studies for context-specific learning, and integrating discussions on digital rights and online advocacy, reflecting the growing role of technology in human rights issues. Logistically, the event was well-organized, with a supportive venue setup, smooth transitions, and effective audiovisual support, making the workshop both informative and engaging for all attendees.

columns.title: Recommendations
content: To enhance future human rights education initiatives, it is recommended to incorporate more interactive and hands-on workshop components that enable participants to design concrete advocacy plans tailored to their communities. Including diverse and localized case studies will help ensure relevance across various social contexts. A follow-up mechanism, such as mentoring programs or periodic networking events, would help sustain momentum and foster continuous learning. Integrating digital rights education and online advocacy tools will also equip participants with modern strategies for promoting human rights. Finally, involving local community leaders, government partners, and civil society organizations can broaden perspectives and strengthen the collaborative impact of future activities.

The unveiling of the World University Rankings 2025 marked a historic milestone for Urdaneta City University (UCU), positioning it within the global dialogue on academic excellence, innovation, and sustainability. The event showcased UCU’s notable achievements in both the World University Rankings for Innovation (WURI) and the Times Higher Education (THE) Impact Rankings, highlighting the university’s dedication to quality education and its meaningful contributions to global development. The ceremony aimed to inspire pride among stakeholders, acknowledge the efforts of faculty and administrators in advancing academic and institutional excellence, and reinforce UCU’s standing in the international education arena. Additionally, it provided a platform to reaffirm UCU’s commitment to the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) through innovative practices and research-driven initiatives.

sections.title: This projects aims to:
items: Present UCU’s official standing in the WURI and THE Impact Rankings 2025.
Inspire faculty, staff, and students to contribute to sustaining and improving global ranking performance.
Provide an avenue for networking and collaboration with academic and industry partners.

sections.title: Contributions to the Sustainable Development Goals
content: The activity directly contributes to several Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), including SDG 4: Quality Education, by highlighting the importance of innovation-driven and inclusive higher education; SDG 9: Industry, Innovation, and Infrastructure, through showcasing UCU’s innovations presented during the ceremony; SDG 10: Reduced Inequalities, by affirming UCU’s role in expanding access to education and promoting equal opportunities; SDG 16: Peace, Justice, and Strong Institutions, by emphasizing the significance of good governance and accountability in institutional development; and SDG 17: Partnerships for the Goals, by strengthening collaborations with partners and stakeholders to advance education and innovation.

columns.title: General Assessment
content: The Unveiling of the World University Rankings 2025 was a successful and memorable event that effectively achieved its goals of recognition, inspiration, and collaboration. It fostered a strong sense of pride and ownership among faculty, students, and staff, reinforcing UCU’s identity as a competitive and globally recognized institution. The program’s balanced mix of cultural performances, formal speeches, and stakeholder testimonials celebrated accomplishments while motivating the academic community to strive for greater heights. A key highlight was the presentation of SDG-aligned innovations, which not only bolstered UCU’s global reputation but also highlighted its unique contributions to sustainable development. The fellowship lunch and networking opportunities further enhanced both institutional and external partnerships. For future events, improvements could include expanding public engagement through live streaming, creating post-event publications summarizing UCU’s achievements, and incorporating student-led innovation showcases to deepen community involvement.

columns.title: Recommendations
content: To further build on the success of this event, it is recommended that Urdaneta City University develop a comprehensive communication plan to effectively publicize its global rankings to both local and international audiences, thereby strengthening visibility and reputation. The university may also institutionalize the annual reporting of its SDG-aligned innovations to ensure consistency and preparedness for future ranking participation. Additionally, capacity-building sessions for faculty and staff should be provided to enhance their contributions to ranking indicators and sustain academic excellence. Students can also be engaged more actively by incorporating innovation fairs and research poster presentations in future unveiling ceremonies, giving them a platform to showcase their creativity and research outputs. Finally, expanding external stakeholder participation to include more representatives from government, industry, and international academic institutions will help broaden partnerships and reinforce UCU’s commitment to global collaboration and impact.

title: 5th Annual Hanseatic league of Universities Conference

content: The 5th Hanseatic League of Universities (HLU) Conference, held on July 9–10, 2025, at Silliman University in Dumaguete City, provided a global platform for academic leaders, innovators, and educators from various countries to foster innovation, collaboration, and societal impact. Centered on promoting transformative education and social responsibility, the conference offered higher education institutions a strategic venue to exchange ideas, share best practices, and explore meaningful partnerships. The Hanseatic League of Universities (HLU) is an international consortium dedicated to advancing innovation and community engagement through its annual conferences, where emerging trends and challenges in higher education and research are discussed. Urdaneta City University (UCU) participated in the event as part of its ongoing commitment to internationalization, academic excellence, and global engagement, aiming to strengthen institutional capacity, build international linkages, and contribute to the global dialogue on the evolving role of higher education in addressing societal needs. The conference’s diverse program—including plenary talks, breakout sessions, and networking opportunities—aligned closely with UCU’s strategic vision of fostering innovation, promoting global partnerships, and enhancing its role in nation-building and community transformation.

sections.title: This projects aims to:
items: Engage in meaningful knowledge exchange and global academic discourse on innovation, international collaboration, and societal impact.
Strengthen UCU’s internationalization initiatives and global partnerships by participating in strategic forums and collaborative sessions.
Gain insights on best practices, trends, and emerging frameworks in higher education, research, and community engagement.

sections.title: Contributions to the Sustainable Development Goals
content: Urdaneta City University’s participation in the 5th Hanseatic League of Universities Conference directly supports several Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). It advances SDG 4: Quality Education by engaging with global leaders and sharing insights to strengthen its commitment to delivering high-quality, transformative education. The focus on innovation, entrepreneurship, and research aligns with SDG 9: Industry, Innovation, and Infrastructure, fostering discussions on integrating cutting-edge practices within higher education. The conference also embodies SDG 17: Partnerships for the Goals by providing a platform for creating collaborative networks that promote shared growth and development. Through involvement in global academic forums, UCU contributes to SDG 10: Reduced Inequalities by helping to reduce disparities in educational opportunities and access to knowledge. Engagement in conversations on employability, skills development, and innovation reflects UCU’s contribution to SDG 8: Decent Work and Economic Growth, emphasizing workforce readiness. Finally, by participating in discussions on social responsibility and sustainability, UCU reaffirms its dedication to SDG 11: Sustainable Cities and Communities through its commitment to community development and civic engagement.

columns.title: General Assessment
content: Urdaneta City University’s participation in the 5th HLU Conference was a strategic and impactful engagement that facilitated knowledge sharing, enhanced UCU’s international presence, and fostered global partnerships aligned with its academic and research goals. The event underscored UCU’s ongoing commitment to innovation, international collaboration, and societal engagement, while reaffirming the university’s strategic direction toward internationalization. Additionally, the conference provided valuable opportunities for reflection and improvement in UCU’s academic and operational practices, making it an effective platform for learning, networking, and institutional advancement.

columns.title: Recommendations
content: Moving forward, it is recommended that UCU sustain active participation in global academic forums like the HLU Conference to continuously expand its network and access global best practices; leverage insights gained for institutional development by integrating innovative approaches and fostering interdisciplinary collaborations inspired by these events; strengthen collaborative research with international partners to boost the university’s research impact and community engagement; promote knowledge sharing within the university by organizing internal dissemination sessions for faculty and staff to maximize the benefits of international participation; and pursue further involvement in international benchmarking and ranking initiatives such as WURI to reinforce UCU’s global standing and leadership in innovation.

title: Training for a Writeshop on Design of Programs for IZN: The UCU Advantage under A.C.H.I.E.V.E.

content: The Writeshop on Internationalization (IZN) was organized to reinforce Urdaneta City University’s strategic focus on enhancing its global academic competitiveness. Guided by the A.C.H.I.E.V.E. framework developed by CHED Chairperson Dr. J. Prospero “Popoy” De Vera III and championed by CHED Chair Shirley Agrupis, the event emphasized creating innovative, globally aligned programs that showcase UCU’s distinctive strengths. This activity provided a collaborative venue for university leaders, faculty, and staff to ideate, design, and plan internationalization programs that respond to both local assets and global opportunities, laying the foundation for sustainable initiatives aimed at strengthening UCU’s presence in the international education arena.

sections.title: This projects aims to:
items: Build institutional capacity in designing and implementing internationalization programs.
Identify UCU’s local strengths and match them with emerging global academic and research opportunities.
Produce initial drafts of IZN programs aligned with UCU’s The UCU Advantage brand.
Strengthen collaboration among university officials, faculty, and external partners toward advancing IZN goals.

sections.title: Contributions to the Sustainable Development Goals
content: The activity directly contributes to several Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), including SDG 4: Quality Education by enhancing access to globally competitive and inclusive academic programs; SDG 8: Decent Work and Economic Growth through developing programs that prepare students for global mobility and employability; SDG 9: Industry, Innovation, and Infrastructure by encouraging innovation in program design aligned with international demands; and SDG 17: Partnerships for the Goals by promoting collaboration with international institutions, industries, and academic partners.

columns.title: General Assessment
content: The Writeshop was a productive and engaging event that successfully achieved its objectives, with participants generating draft internationalization (IZN) programs that reflected creativity, institutional pride, and global relevance. The program was well-balanced, combining ideation, presentation, and planning phases effectively. The active involvement of top administrators, including the Acting University President and COO, underscored the institution’s strong commitment to internationalization, while Dr. Soriano’s facilitation ensured that the outputs were actionable rather than purely conceptual. Areas for improvement include incorporating more benchmarking presentations from partner universities, involving student voices in program ideation, and standardizing documentation of outputs to facilitate easier monitoring and implementation.

columns.title: Recommendations
content: To sustain the momentum from this writeshop, it is recommended to institutionalize the activity as an annual or semi-annual event to continuously generate and refine internationalization (IZN) programs; develop a monitoring framework for these programs with clear milestones, responsible units, and timelines; expand collaboration by inviting external experts and partner institutions to future writeshops to enrich perspectives; produce a consolidated IZN program portfolio to serve as UCU’s blueprint for internationalization efforts; and integrate student participation in future IZN activities to ensure inclusivity and foster innovation from the grassroots level.
